title: Note-Level Singing Melody Transcription for Time-Aligned Musical Score Generation
author: Leekyung Kim (Seoul National University), Sungwook Jeon (Seoul National University), Wan Heo (Seoul National University), Jonghun Park (Seoul National University)
relevance_why: The paper addresses audio-to-score transcription, which aligns with Haohe Liu's interest in audio processing. Techniques for note transcription could inform similar methods in his work on audio generation and enhancement.
background: This paper focuses on converting audio recordings of vocal melodies into symbolic musical scores, capturing pitch, onset, offset, and note value directly from audio inputs.
contribution: This paper introduces an end-to-end framework to solve the challenge of generating time-aligned musical scores from singing melodies, achieving superior transcription performance compared to existing methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods rely on multi-stage processes for note segmentation and transcription, which can lead to errors during each stage.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work presents a unified model that predicts multiple attributes (onset, offset, pitch, note value) simultaneously, eliminating error propagation common in traditional methods.

key_innovation: The integration of a new tokenized representation that includes note values allows for direct generation of time-aligned scores in an end-to-end manner.
real_world_impact: The proposed transcription system can enhance applications in music educational tools and automated score generation, facilitating better access to musical notation.
limitations: The performance is still dependent on the quality of existing datasets for training, which may limit generalization to diverse music styles.

new_terms.time-aligned score: **Time-aligned score** refers to a musical score that synchronizes visually represented notes with their actual timing in recorded audio.
new_terms.pseudo-labeling: **Pseudo-labeling** is a semi-supervised learning technique where a model generates labels for unannotated data using predictions from an initially trained model.
